application_type_full: Prior Approval: Change of use - offices to dwellinghouses
description: Change of use from Office (Class B1(a)) to self-contained dwellings (one-bed, two-bed and studio flats) (Class C3).
decision_conditions: The proposed development is considered to be in accordance with Schedule 2, Part 3, Class O of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order (England) 2015 (as amended).

No development shall commence until a site investigation scheme based on the desk study together with assessment of risks posed by any contamination is carried out in accordance with British Standard BS10175: Investigation of Potentially Contaminated Sites - Code of Practice and the Environment Agency's Model Procedures for the Management of Land Contamination (CLR 11) (or equivalent British Standard and Model Procedures if replaced), has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. Should remediation be required, no development shall commence until a report specifying the measures to be taken, including the timescale, to remediate the site to render it suitable for use shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.

Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and to prevent harm to human health and pollution of the environment in accordance with Policy 5.21 of the London Plan, 2016.

Prior to occupation of the development, a verification report demonstrating completion of the works set out in the approved remediation strategy and the effectiveness of the remediation shall be submitted to and approved, in writing, by the local planning authority. The report shall include results of sampling and monitoring carried out in accordance with the approved verification plan to demonstrate that the site remediation criteria have been met. It shall also include any plan (a "long-term monitoring and maintenance plan") for longer-term monitoring of pollutant linkages, maintenance and arrangements for contingency action, as identified in the verification plan, if appropriate, and for the reporting of this to the local planning authority. Any long-term monitoring and maintenance plan shall be implemented as approved. 

Reason: Should remediation be deemed necessary, the applicant should demonstrate that any remedial measures have been undertaken as agreed and the environmental risks have been satisfactorily managed so that the site is deemed suitable for use and to prevent harm to human health and pollution of the environment in accordance with Policy 5.21 of the London Plan, 2016.

If during development, contamination not previously identified is found to be present at the site then no further development (unless otherwise agreed in writing with the Local Planning Authority) shall be carried out until the developer has submitted, and obtained written approval from the Local Planning Authority for, a remediation strategy detailing how this unsuspected contamination shall be dealt with. The remediation strategy shall be implemented as approved, verified and reported to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. 

Reason: There is always the potential for unexpected contamination to be identified during development groundworks. The Local Planning Authority should be consulted should any contamination be identified that could present an unacceptable risk to Controlled Waters to prevent harm to human health and pollution of the environment in accordance with Policy 5.21 of the London Plan, 2016

Prior to commencement of groundworks (excluding site investigations and demolition), the applicant must submit a final detailed drainage design including drawings, supporting calculations and updated Drainage Assessment Form to the Lead Local Flood Authority for review and approval, aligned with the Flood Risk Assessment (report reference. 58996, revision v1.0, date November 2020) and associated drawings. Details regarding runoff rate and attenuation volume should be suitably provided and approved in writing by the Lead Local Flood Authority. A detailed management plan confirming routine maintenance tasks for all drainage components must also be submitted to demonstrate how the drainage system is to be maintained for the lifetime of the development.
 
Reason: To prevent the risk of flooding to and from the site in accordance with relevant policy requirements including but not limited to London Plan Policy SI 13, its associated Sustainable Design and Construction SPG, the Non-Statutory Technical Standards for Sustainable Drainage Systems and Kingston Council's Local Plan Policy DM4.

No building hereby permitted shall be occupied until evidence (photographs and installation contracts) is submitted to demonstrate that the sustainable drainage scheme for the site has been completed in accordance with the submitted details. The sustainable drainage scheme shall be managed and maintained thereafter in accordance with the agreed management and maintenance plan for all of the proposed drainage components.
 
Reason: To comply with the Non-Statutory Technical Standards for Sustainable Drainage Systems, the National Planning Policy Framework (Paragraph 103), the London Plan (Policies SI 12 and SI 13) along with associated guidance to these policies and Kingston Council's Local Plan Policy DM4.

A Car Park Management Plan demonstrating how the use of the car park will be controlled and detailing the signage necessary within the site to direct pedestrians and vehicles shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority prior to first occupation. It should also demonstrate how any future occupants of the residential units hereby approved will be prevented from applying for both residential and visitor parking permits for parking within the Controlled Parking Zone surrounding the application site. The management plan shall include a completed unilateral undertaking under Section 16 of the Greater London Council (General Powers) Act 1974. The units shall not be occupied until the Car Parking Management Plan is approved The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details and thereafter permanently retained.

Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policies DM9 (Managing Vehicle Use for New Development) and Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The car parking, servicing and manoeuvring areas shown on the approved drawings shall be provided with a hard, bound, dust-free surface, adequately drained before the development is occupied for the purpose hereby permitted.  The respective areas shall be kept free from obstruction at all times, and shall not thereafter be used for any other purposes other than those shown on the approved drawing. 

Reason:  To ensure that the proposed development does not prejudice the free flow of traffic or conditions of general safety on adjoining highways and that adequate parking servicing and manoeuvring provision is made in accordance with Policies DM9 (Managing Vehicle Use for New Development) and Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to first occupation, a Delivery and Service Plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved plan and thereafter permanently retained.

Reason: In order to ensure proper delivery and service management in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a travel plan comprising immediate, continuing and long-term measures to promote and encourage alternatives to single-occupancy car use shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved plan shall then be implemented and monitored to the satisfaction of the local planning authority, having regard to the targets contained within it. 

Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to first occupation, details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, the development hereby approved shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.

Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to commencement of development a full Construction Logistics Plan should be provided that demonstrates that construction will not negatively impact the operation of the Transport for London Road Network (TLRN) nor reduce bus journey time reliability. Transport for London (TfL) have produced guidance for applicants producing Construction Logistics Plans (CLP), which should be followed. TfL's guidance can be accessed here:  http://content.tfl.gov.uk/construction-logistics-plan-guidance.pdf.

- It is requested that the applicant uses FORS and CLOCS registered vehicles for all construction and delivery vehicles serving the site. However, the Mayor is in the process of implementing more stringent Direct Vision Standards (DVS) across London starting in October 2020. The applicant should make sure that all vehicles comply with the DVS standards also.
- TfL requests that deliveries are not scheduled during peak hours. This is in the interests of road safety in line with the Mayor's Vision Zero target.
- TfL requests that the applicant proposes the use of a banksman on site ensuring vehicles can enter and exit the site safely, and the management of pedestrians and cyclists, in line with the Vision Zero Standards.
- TfL request evidence that vehicles can enter and exit in forward gear, this should take the form of a swept path analysis to ensure safety on the road in line with the Vision Zero Standards.
- All vehicles associated with the installation works must only park/stop at permitted locations and within the time periods permitted by existing on-street restrictions.

Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to ensure proper delivery and service management in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Introduction
This application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  

Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents.
 
By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.

The Development Plan comprises:

The London Plan 2021;
RBK Core Strategy 2012;
Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,
The South London Waste Plan 2022.

This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.

Consultations
3 no surrounding properties were notified  of the proposed development. No  letters of representation were received.  

Comments received : 
Kingston and North Kingston Conservation Areas Advisory Committee  - Objection 
We agree that the existing rear extension of the property can be improved upon. That said, we find the stepped profile of the new enlarged rear extension e.g. when viewed from the south to be out of character with the existing  property and architectural typology of its neighbours. It would be clearly visible from the public highway and in our view conflict with the character and appearance of the Conservation Area. Furthermore, we find the proposed materials palette overly elaborate and confusing, comprising brickwork,stone, timber (+ aluminium fenestration) finishes.

We recommend that the profile of the proposed rear extension is simplified, more akin to the smoother outline of the existing extension. In addition, we recommend that the range of materials is reduced eg comprise brickwork throughout (+aluminium or timber fenestration)

RBK Tree Officer -   No objection, satisfied with the proposals and the Arboricultural Submission .No objection .

RBK Heritage and Conservation - Objection. Acknowledges the existing extension is already overly large and dominant and in need of improvement. The proposal exacerbates this condition by extending further back on the side which is visible to the public highway. This would step back further than the single storey extensions on the neighbouring dwellings on the street. The stepped form and range of materials are overly complicated.. The officer recommends that the proposal be rationalised with a single storey element following the footprint of the existing extension, with a taller element also following the existing arrangement, ideally with a pitched roof. London stock brick should be the primary material

Proposal 
The application seeks full planning permission for the erection of a single storey rear, first floor rear extensions. Fenestration and internal alterations.

Application Site
The site comprises a detached dwelling. 

The application site is within a  Liverpool Road Conservation Area and does not comprise of a statutory or locally listed building.  Area of Archaeological Significance 2.5 Coombe Hill. 

Planning History
14/12570/TCA - T.1 Laurel - Fell (outgrown location and causing damage to drive). Granted 06.07.14
14/12353/TCA - T.1 Ash - Re - pollard to previous points. Granted 22.0.14
05/12245/REM - Amended railing details pursuant to condition 2 of planning permission 05/12057/FUL and condition 2 of conservation area consent 05/12092/CAC. Granted 22.04.05
05/12092/CAC - Demolition of existing steps to front door and replacement with new; excavation of front lightwell and installation of steps and front door to basement. Granted 23.03.05
05/12057/FUL - Excavation of front lightwell and installation of steps and new doorway to basement; replacement of steps to front door. Granted 23.03.05
04/12634/TCA - Felling of Yew trees in a conservation area. Granted 22.10.04
04/12259/TCA - Surgery work to Yew and Cherry trees in conservation area. Granted 27.08.04
98/03347/TCA - Surgery work to Eucalyptus, ew, Lawson Cypress, Conifer and Pear trees in Conservation Area. Granted 30.10.98
93/0557/TCA - Felling of Lime trees in Conservation Area. Granted 16.06.93
30341 - Erection of conservatory at rear. Granted 13.09.85

Planning Assessment  
The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development; and,
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.
- Impact upon heritage assets
- Fire Safety 

Design
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale , appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.

Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. 

Officer comment :
The existing rear extension presents a two storey 'contemporary' glazed extension which extends from the vernacular above ground floor level  to the lower ground floor level (basement). It is understood that the design principle and purpose of the glazed roof and rear elevation was twofold to allow light through into the host dwelling and provide visual access to the original rear elevation.

The proposal seeks to replace the existing structure with the erection of a reduced height two storey 'stepped' rear extension on the same footprint  with an additional single storey extension on the lower ground level which would provide access to the garden.  It is noted that the proposed single storey extension would  not extend the full width of the host dwelling and be positioned on the south west side. Glazing would remain a key design feature of the new  rear elevation.The proposed  roofs for each extension  element would be flat. 

In respect of the north elevation and the proposed lower ground floor level, Officers note that a section of the elevation brick wall of the kitchen/ dining area would be extended out towards no.19 Queens Drive. It would have a proposed height of 1.97m and accommodate fixed glazing to provide light to the basement kitchen.  

In terms of the south side elevation, the proposed extension would present a 'stepped' built form profile  along the site boundary. It would extend  8.235m from the rear elevation of the original house. The proposed single storey extension would protrude  2.213m beyond the building line of the existing extension. The proposed height of the two storey  extension abutting the house would be 4.207m stepping down to 3.294m and then to 2.269m for the single storey element. In this location the topography is gently slopingNo new fenestration is proposed along this elevation.   Officers note the south side elevation of the proposed extension would be visible from both the public highway and from the access road which runs parallel.

In respect of the appearance of proposed rear elevation, Officers note a combination of materials are proposed for the various features. The existing external outrigger is to be  white rendered to match the appearance of the internal outrigger at lower level.  Officers would not be supportive of this visual  change as it would alter the overall appearance of the external rear elevation  of the host dwelling. However, Officers  note a new sash window is proposed for the outrigger to match the existing windows on the host dwelling. This is deemed acceptable. Officers note glazing would remain a key design feature of the new elevation to be framed by a new stone facade.  Large new aluminium sliding doors are to be introduced.

 Within the context of the existing built form, Officers consider that the proposed rear extension in terms of its design, form and use of materials  would not appear to be a proportionate and subordinate addition to the main dwellinghouse  and therefore not be considered to be acceptable from a character and design perspective. 


Neighbouring Amenities
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.

Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

Officer Comment:  
Given the proportionate and subordinate nature  of the proposed development and its siting in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. 

Heritage Assets
Section 66 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) states that in considering whether to grant planning permission for development which affects a listed building or its setting, the local planning authority shall have special regard to the desirability of preserving the building or its setting or any features of special architectural or historic interest which it possesses.

Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                  
Paragraphs 195 - 208 of the NPPF (2023) set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets (including non-designated heritage assets). Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.

When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.

Officers  acknowledge that the proposed  replacement rear extension based on the  design, form and use of materials would not preserve or enhance the character or appearance of the Liverpool Road Conservation Area resulting in less than substantial harm to the Conservation Area. In the absence of any public benefits that would outweigh this harm, the proposal is in conflict with Policy D3, HC1 of the London Plan (2021) and Policies CS8, DM 10, DM11 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012) and Residential Design Guide SPD (2013).

Fire safety 
London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.

Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. 

Conclusion
In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Details of the Application Submission
In accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.

https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

--- Informatives ---

Positive and Proactive
In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

Building Regulations
Your attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.

Party Wall Act
The Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:

- carry out work to an existing party wall;
- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;
- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.

Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".

Property Boundaries
Your attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.

Consistency of Plans
Reasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.

Construction Site Noise
When undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  

You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.

Definition of Approved in Writing
Where reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.

Ground Level / Base Level
Unless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

Introduction
This application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  

Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents.
 
By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.

The Development Plan comprises:

The London Plan 2021;
RBK Core Strategy 2012;
Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,
The South London Waste Plan 2022.

This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.

Consultations
5 no surrounding properties were notified  of the proposed development. No  letters of representation were received.  1 letter of objection has been received stating : 
- Excessive height or bulk of buildings
- Loss of light/sunlight

Comments have  also been raised in respect  of the following : 
- the proposed height resulting in the parapet wall between nos 38 and 40  Tudor Drive be reduced in height impacting upon the lead flashing on the new flat roof of no 38
- Reference on proposed rear elevation drawing ' proposed flank wall position to be similar to existing flank wall' raising the question whether  the entire wall is to be rebuilt or stitching in of matching brick work
- The fence between nos 38 and 40 will need to be modified with new Jacksons post and fence panel

The issues above are civil matters. 

Proposal 
The application seeks full planning permission for the demolition of an existing rear conservatory and erection of a single storey rear extension.

Application Site
The  site comprises  a two storey semi detached dwelling. 

Planning History
23/01905/HOU - Demolition of rear conservatory and construction of single storey rear extension . Refused 5.10.23

Planning Assessment  
The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development; and,
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.
- Fire Safety 

Design
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale , appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.

Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. 

Officer comment : The proposal seeks  full planning permission for the erection of a single storey rear extension which would have a depth of  3.5m  and would extend the full width  of the host dwelling. It would have a proposed  flat roof height of  2.9m. Proposed materials  and external finishes would be masonry and render with aluminium windows.

Within the context of the existing built form on site and the siting of the single storey  rear extension, it is considered that the proposal would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition to the main dwellinghouse and that it would be acceptable from a character and design perspective.

Neighbouring Amenities
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.

Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

Officer Comment:  
The principal properties to consider in relation to amenity is neighbouring property are nos 38 and 42 Tudor Drive. 

In response to the previous  refused planning application, Officers note that the proposed single storey rear extension has been reduced in terms of its depth and would no longer present an overbearing appearance both on the shared boundary and from the garden of no 38 Tudor Drive.

In respect of no 42 Tudor Drive, it would be considered that the proposed extension would not present an overbearing impact on the basis of the close proximity of the built form to the boundary.

The current  planning application is accompanied by a Daylight, Sunlight and Overshadowing Assessment (November 2023). The Assessment has been reviewed and Officers are satisfied with the presented findings that the proposed development would not  have a significantly adverse impact  in terms of both daylight and sunlight. 

Overall, It is considered that the proposed development would have not adversely affect the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. 

Fire safety 
London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.

The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation  assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12 (A). the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons. Officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.

Conclusion
In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

In accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.

--- Informatives ---

Positive and Proactive
In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

Building Regulations
Your attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.

Party Wall Act
The Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:

- carry out work to an existing party wall;
- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;
- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.

Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".

Property Boundaries
Your attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.

Consistency of Plans
Reasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.

Construction Site Noise
When undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  

You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.

Definition of Approved in Writing
Where reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.

Ground Level / Base Level
Unless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.



Details of the Application Submission
In accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.

https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

Application Site
The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling that currently benefits from a rear dormer loft conversion.

Proposal
Installation of solar panels on main roof and rear extension roof

This application follows recent application (23/01098/HOU dated 15.08.2023) which was refused for the following reason;

1) Due to an inconsistancy with the plans it has not been possible to measure the extent of harm that may be caused by the view of the proposed solar panels above the existing ridge height contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.

This reason for refusal would need to be addressed in order for this application to be successful.

Consultation
6 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.

Assessment
The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development; 
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,
- Fire safety. 

Design
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.

Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.

Officer Comment: Officers note that the proposed Solar Panels would be visible from medium to longer range views to the north and south. They would appear incongruous, causing some harm to the character and appearance of the area. The panels would project approximately 0.7m above the flat roof ridge height when raised and approximately 0.5m when flat, which would add a distinctly industrial appearance to the dominant ridge line shared by properties along this side of the road. The solar panels at the single storey level are considered to be acceptable in isolation.

Neighbouring Amenities
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.

Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.

Sustainability
The purpose of the planning system is to contribute to the achievement of sustainable development. Achieving sustainable development means that the planning system has an environmental objective - to contribute to protecting and enhancing our natural, built and historic environment; including making effective use of land, helping to improve biodiversity, using natural resources prudently, minimising waste and pollution, and mitigating and adapting to climate change, including moving to a low carbon economy.

Kingston Council has declared a Climate Emergency, and Policy DM10 encourages the incorporation of sustainable design and construction requirements. Within this context, the provision of solar panels would make a contribution, albeit limited, towards a low carbon transition.

Fire Safety
London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.

Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.

Conclusion & Planning balance
Officers acknowledge positive, albeit limited, sustainability benefits of the proposal. However, it is not considered that this limited benefit would outweigh the identified harm to the character and appearance of the area. It is therefore recommended that planning permission is refused.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.

7 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representation has been received. 

The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development.
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.
- Fire Safety

Design
When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.

Officer Comment: Officers acknowledge the proposed dormer would not be visible from the streetscene, however, the roof extension would not strictly comply with Residential Design SPD in regards to retaining a 500mm distance from the sides, the eaves and the ridge line and the block finish for the dormer would appear bulky. Additionally, the proposed zinc cladding on the roof extension would not respect the exterior materials of the existing dwelling and would accentuate the bulk of the dormer which would be highly visible from neighbouring properties. The proposed dormer would not be permitted development.

It is noted that the proposed wrap-around single-storey side extension would not appear as part of the original building, due to the low-pitched zinc roof, however, it would not significantly harm the character and appearance of the streetscene. 

Overall, the proposed development is considered to be unacceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, materials and design and design. It is considered that there would be adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.

Amenity
Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

Officer comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.

Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.

Fire Safety
London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.

Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Report which suitably addresses the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.

In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2023), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Introduction
This application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  

Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents.
 
By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.

This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.

Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.

The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:

- The London Plan 2021
- The South London Waste Plan 2022 
- The LDF Core Strategy 2012
- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008

Application Site
The site comprises an end of terrace dwelling.

Proposal
The application seeks  full planning permission for the demolition of the existing rear extension, erection of a single storey rear, front infill and first floor side extension. Fenestration alterations.

Consultation
3 no surrounding properties were notified  of the proposed development. No  letters of representation were received. 

Assessment
The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development; and,
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of and and buildings.

Design
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.

Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. 

The proposal seeks to demolish the existing rear extension to the dwelling and erect a single storey rear, front infill and first floor side extension accompanied with fenestration alterations.

The  existing rear extension  is a conservatory and at its widest ('bay' window) has a depth of 3.58m.  It has an existing width of 5.31m.The proposed rear extension would extend a depth of 4.2m and width of 8.43m which would accommodate the further extension of the existing side extension. The proposed height of the rear extension would be 3.312m to the eaves and 3.573m to the pitch of the proposed rooflight.   Overall, Officers note that the proposed depth of the extension would be contrary to Policy Guidance 33 in the Residential Design SPD and therefore would not be considered to be a proportionate and subordinate addition to the dwelling.

In addition to the above, the proposal seeks permission for a first floor side extension which would be accommodated within  the   reduced building footprint of the ground floor side extension.  This additional floor level  would result in a change of roof form of the side extension reverting from a flat roof to a hipped roof form arrangement .Overall, the addition  of both the proposed first floor extension and the hipped roof form to the existing side extension would fail to appear subordinate or proportionate  and unduly reduce  the gap between the dwelling and its neighbouring dwelling at no 47 Compton Crescent. This element of the proposed development is therefore considered to be unacceptable in terms of scale, siting and design. It is considered that there would be unacceptable adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposals.

The proposal seeks approval for a front infill to the dwelling between the garage and the front door in order to create internal floorspace to accommodate a shower room.   Officers note this would be set back from the front building line of the property and this would be deemed acceptable.  

In addition, Officers note the proposal also includes the introduction of a monopitch tiled roof to front the garage, infill and the front door. This would alter the character and appearance of the front elevation of the dwelling and would be deemed acceptable.

Officers note  proposed materials would match existing.

Overall, the proposed development is therefore considered to be unacceptable in terms of scale, siting and design. It is considered that there would be unacceptable adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposals.

Neighbouring Amenities
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.

Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

The principal property to consider in relation to amenity is neighbouring property at no 51 Compton Crescent.

Given the siting and depth of the proposed development  hard on the boundary with no 51, it is considered that the proposed development would result in the significant loss of daylight to the closest habitable room at ground level in comparison with the existing situation. 

In addition given the siting and depth of the proposed development along the shared boundary with no 51, it is considered that the proposed development would constitute an unneighbourly form of development and present an overbearing appearance in the location.

Overall, given the size of the proposed development and its siting in relation to neighbouring no. 51 Compton Crescent, it is considered that the proposed development would adversely affect the amenities of occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance and loss of light .

Conclusion
In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Application Site
The site comprises a mid-terrace dwelling within the Kingston Vale Conservation Area. The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as: An early Victorian village on the London to Portsmouth Road at the Robin Hood Gate entrance to Richmond Park and Wimbledon Common. The village is made up of an eclectic mix of mainly small-scale housing and community uses.

Proposal
Erection of single storey rear extension and rear dormer roof extension with 3nos. front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Formation of new driveway and vehicular crossover.

Consultation
6 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.

Malden & Coombe CAAC: No objection subject to the roof windows being conservation grade to the front elevation.

RBK Highways Surgery - No objection after discussing application in the meeting. Applicant should be made aware that they are liable for any costs relating to the movement of utilities outside the property that may be required should a crossover licence be granted. However, it is noted that this is not a planning matter and more of a courtesy to the applicant.

Assessment
The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development; 
- The impact of the proposal on heritage assets;
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; 
- Fire Safety; and,
- The impact of the development on the highway.

Design
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.

Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.

Officer Comment: It is noted that a number of properties within this terrace already benefit from similar loft coversions, rear extensions and dropped kerbs. The proposed development is therefore considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.

Heritage Assets
Section 66 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) states that in considering whether to grant planning permission for development which affects a listed building or its setting, the local planning authority shall have special regard to the desirability of preserving the building or its setting or any features of special architectural or historic interest which it possesses.

Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                  
Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.

When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.

Officer Comment: Due to the location of the proposal, officers consider that the proposed development would preserve the character and appearance of the Kingston Vale Conservation Area and would not cause any harm to the significance of the designated heritage asset. Since no harm has been identified it is not necessary to weigh the proposal against any public benefit.

Neighbouring Amenities
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.

Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

Officer Comment: The proposed rear extension would not exceed 3m and would be inline with the existing outrigger on the property. Overall, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.

Fire Safety
London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.

Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.

Highway Safety
The NPPF requires that in assessing applications for development, it is ensured that: appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport modes can be - or have been - taken up; safe and suitable access to the site can be achieved for all users; and any significant impacts from the development on the transport network (in terms of capacity and congestion), or on highway safety, can be cost effectively mitigated to an acceptable degree.

Development should only be prevented or refused on highways grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or the residual cumulative impacts on the road network would be severe.

Policies DM9 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy together with the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 seek to ensure that new development has regard to local traffic conditions and does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety and for proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.

Officers Comments: It is annotated on Drawing No: PT228PL01-2B that boundary treatment along the front would comprise a new 1.5m high brick wall; the proposed wall has not been shown on other drawings. On the basis of the submitted information it is likely that the proposed boundary treatment would not accord with the visibility requirements set out in the Vehicule Crossover Policy (April 2020). If erected at the suggested height the proposal could adversley impact pedestrian safety. Therefore, it is necessary to require details of front boundary treatment (which fully complies with the visibility requirements of the Vehicle Crossover Policy 2020) to be submitted prior to the erection of any front boundary treatment. Subject to this planning condition it is considered that the proposal would be acceptable from a highway safety perspective.

Conclusion
In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".

Property Boundaries
Your attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.

Consistency of Plans
Reasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.

Construction Site Noise
When undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  

You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.

Definition of Approved in Writing
Where reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.

Ground Level / Base Level
Unless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

Introduction
This application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  

Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents.
 
By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.

The Development Plan comprises:

The London Plan 2021;
RBK Core Strategy 2012;
Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,
The South London Waste Plan 2022.

This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.

Consultations
9 no surrounding properties were notified  of the proposed development. No  letters of representation were received.  

Proposal 
The application seeks full planning permission for the erection of a hip to gable and rear dormer roof extension and installation of 3no. Front rooflights to the first floor flat.

Application Site
The  site comprises  a flat dwelling located within the Kingston Hill/ Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character . 

Relevant History
115 Vale Crescent. 
23/02676/FUL - Erection of hip to gable roof extension with rear dormer and installation of 3nos front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Granted 17.11.23

127 Vale Crescent 
22/102904/FUL - Erection of hip to gable and rear dormer roof extension and installation of 3.no rooflights to front roofscape to first floor  flat. Granted 27.10.22

87 Vale Crescent 
21/03992/HOU - Erection of hip to gable and rear dormer roof extension with installation of 3no. Front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Granted 10.02.22

35 Vale Crescent
22/01875/FUL - Erection of hip to gable roof extension with rear dormer and juliet balcony and installation of 3nos front rooflights and 2 nos rooflights on top of flat roof to facilitate loft conversion. Granted 12.08.22


Planning Assessment  
The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development; and,
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.
- Fire Safety 

Design
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale , appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.

Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. 

Officer comment : The proposal seeks for the  erection of a hip to gable and rear dormer roof extension and installation of 3no. Front rooflights to the first floor flat. Proposed materials and external finishes are to match existing.

Paragraphs 195 to 208 of the NPPF (December 2023) set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.

When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated or non designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and more important  the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.

The proposal does not fully comply with the guiding principles of the adopted Residential Design  SPD in terms of the proposed dormer would  not set down from the ridge line of the existing roof by at least 500mm  - presented as 186mm on proposed rear elevation (drawing 2023/150-03). In terms of  setting in from   the sides and eaves of the roof by at least 500mm, the proposed elevations for side and rear  are compliant with the SPD. In the material consideration of the permissions granted for similar extensions at neighbouring properties as outlined in the relevant history section (which altered the hipped roof form to a gable end) are consistent with the proposed development.

It is considered that in this instance and in the context of its surroundings to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and the proposal would not have an adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area or the non designated heritage asset of Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area. 

Neighbouring Amenities
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.

Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

Officer Comment:  
Given the proportionate and subordinate nature  of the proposed development and its siting in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. 

Fire safety 
London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.

Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. 
Conclusion
In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Details of the Application Submission
