Officer Report

Application Site
The site comprises a semi detached dwelling located within the Area of Archaeological Significance.

Proposal 
Conversion of garage into habitable space, erection of a single storey garage infill and rear extension. While not explicitly stated within the description of development, from looking at the existing/proposed plans it is apparent that the garage conversion works would include alterations/replacement to the existing garage roof.

Consultations
4 properties were notified of the proposal.

Two representations have been received objecting to the proposal, with comments summarised as follows:
- Inappropriate design/layout
- Unacceptable or incompatible use
- The proposal will encroach on the adjoining property 
- The proposal as built on the boundary may result in damage to the adjoining buildings and structures
- Excessive height or bulk of buildings 
- Inadequate landscaping/means of enclosure
- Noise
- Privacy
- The proposal will impact the existing, shared drainage system

Officer response: Any matters controlled under non-planning laws, a separate sewer regime (Thames Water), building regulations or problems arising from the construction period which would be covered by a Party Wall Agreement are not material planning considerations and they cannot be included within the assessment. Any other concerns raised with the written representations will be addressed with this report.

Relevant planning history:
23/01901/HOU for Conversion of garage into habitable space and erection of first floor side extension - Refused

23/02503/PAEXT for Erection of single storey rear extension (6.0m in depth, maximum height of 3.3m and eaves height of 2.70m) - Refused

23/01902/PAEXT for Erection of single storey rear extension (6.0m in depth, maximum height of 3.30m and eaves height of 2.70m) - Refused

23/01859/CPU for Erection of outbuilding - Granted

23/01861/CPU for Erection of hip to gable extension and rear dormer with 2no rooflights to facilitate loft conversion - Granted

The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development; and,
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,
- Fire Safety

Character and Appearance
When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. 

Officer Comment: The proposal is for conversion of the existing garage that abuts the common boundary into habitable room and erection of a single storey rear, infill extension of the total depth of approximately 2.1m. The proposed eaves height of the side extension would be similar to the existing one, approximately 2.8m high. The proposed rear extension element of the proposal would be of similar eaves height, however it would be finished in pitched roof of the total height of approximately 3.7m. 

A concern has been raised in written representations that the proposal would encroach on the adjoining property No 24. The submitted plans clearly show that the proposal would be contained within the red line boundary. It is noted that certificate A of the application form has been signed and submitted.

However, the proposal would be set along the common boundary and no information with regards to the proposed drainage system has been provided. The submitted photographs of the dwelling show that the existing gutters are overhanging the adjoining property and this was not captured on the submitted existing plans. 

Policy Guidance 35 of the Council's Residential Design SPD recommends that the extension should be set in from the boundary at least 250 mm so guttering does not overhang adjoining land. 

In this case, as the existing garage and rear extension are situated on the boundary, the proposed siting of the rear extension may be acceptable, however the proposal must not encroach on the adjoining property. Considering submitted information, the photographs of the application site and no details of the proposed drainage system, it is unclear how drainage could be accommodated without making changes to the scheme as proposed (such as a change in roof form and height), if the drainage is not to go beyond the scope of the current application which is indicated to be contained wholly on land within the applicant's ownership. Details of drainage could not be secured by planning condition in this case as either neighbouring land would be required to accommodate drainage or material amendments would be required to the design of the extension so that drainage could be contained wholly within the application site.

With regards to the proposed mass and bulk of the proposal, it is considered to be acceptable and in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. The proposed rear extension given its modest scale and the proposed design is considered to be acceptable. 

Neighbouring Amenities
Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

Officer Comment: Officers note the existing rear extension at No 28 Manor Drive North. Given the modest eaves height of the proposal, its depth and siting, it is considered that it would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight in relation to the nearest habitable windows at the ground floor level and it would not to appear as an overbearing when viewed from the rear garden at No 28.

With regards to No 24 Manor Drive North, due to the siting of the proposal and its scale, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy

Loss of Car Parking
Paragraph 115 of the NPPF, 2023 states that development should only be prevented or refused on transport grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or where the residual cumulative impacts of development are severe. 

Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires development proposals to have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected. 

Officer Comment:  Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate 2 off street car parking spaces, therefore the proposal would not result in an unacceptable impact on the local highway network. 

In relation to cycle parking, the applicant failed to demonstrate secure cycle parking provision to compensate for the loss of the garage. However Officers note that this provision may be located within the existing amenity space, details of which could be secured via condition. 

Fire Safety
London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.

The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.

The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Statement, which covers some of the requirements of Policy D12(A). However, a more detailed Fire Safety Statement will be required by way of a planning condition to ensure that the development achieves the highest standards of fire safety and fully addresses the requirements of Policy D12(A), as is set out within the London Plan Guidance - Fire Safety.

Conclusion
In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Application Site
The application site comprises a semi-detached dwellinghouse and is located within Claremont Road Conservation Area. The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as: Part of the original Surbiton "New Town" conceived by Thomas Pooley. Development started in 1838, and centred around the landscaped Claremont Crescent Gardens.

Proposal
Repair and retention of the existing means of enclosure.

The enclosure in question is subject to a Dangerous Structure notification by RBK Building Control Department (22/05033/ACCDS)

Consultation
10 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.

Surbiton CAAC - The repairs to the wall are acceptable but the loss of 2 protected trees is a concern. Alternative structural designs should be considered that permit the retention of the trees.

RBK Tree Officer - Permission has already been received for removal for trees under 23/03148/TCA dated 28.11.2023. No Objection subject to condition requiring replacement trees.

RBK Heritage Officer - supportive of the retention and repair of the existing wall, in a like-for-like manner. This permission is only for the localised remedial works as shown in 221293-SK-S-001, as I note the Structural Appraisal Report outlines the recommended 'short terms repairs', including a long term management plan that may conclude a full replacement of the wall in the future. No objection subject to condition requiring samples of materials

Assessment
The key areas of assessment are:
- The design of the proposed development; 
- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,
- The impact of the development on trees.

Design
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.

Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.

Officer Comment: The wall will be retained and repaired. Subject to a condition regarding proposed material details, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.

Neighbouring Amenities
Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.

Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.

Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.

Trees
Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) states that The Council will expect new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders are not adversely affected. Policy Guidance 7 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) state that generally there will be a presumption against the loss of trees - regardless of whether they are protected by virtue of a Tree Preservation Order or with respect to their location within a designated Conservation Area.

Where trees are to be lost through development the Council will normally require the planting of two specimens for each tree lost. The Council will refuse applications that adversely impact upon the leafy character of the Borough where commensurate appropriate replacement is not provided.

The Council encourages the planting of native species. Where new tree species are to be introduced, a preference will be given to native species, where these native species represent the dominant character of the landscape (e.g. in proximity to a woodland setting) or disease/pollution resistant species, where proposed in close proximity to motorised traffic.

The Council discourages the planting of invasive or aggressive species, particularly where these species are proposed to be planted in close proximity to a neighbour's wall, fence or other structure. Large-canopied species are also discouraged.

Officers Comment: It is noted that permission for removal of trees has been granted under 23/03148/TCA. The tree officer has recommended that a condition regarding replacement tree be applied should permission be granted.

Conclusion
In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
